notes.title: Operating Systems: VM, Scheduling, Deadlocks
notes.content: Core OS areas that repeat: virtual memory (paging/segmentation, TLB), CPU scheduling (FCFS, SJF, RR, priority), and deadlocks (Coffman conditions; prevention/avoidance/detection). Study kernel responsibilities (interrupts, exceptions, system calls) and DMA basics for I/O.
keyTakeaways: Virtual memory lets processes see large contiguous address spaces; paging enables isolation and efficient memory use.
Know Gantt charts for FCFS, SJF/Preemptive SJF, Round-Robin; compute waiting/turnaround times.
Deadlock = mutual exclusion + hold & wait + no preemption + circular wait; break at least one to prevent.
Kernel handles interrupts/exceptions; user↔kernel mode transitions via system calls.

resources.title: MIT 6.828 Operating System Engineering (overview + materials)
resources.description: Rigorous OS course: virtual memory, interrupts, syscalls.

notes.title: Data Structures & Algorithms (DSA): Searching, Sorting, Hashing, Trees/Graphs
notes.content: Master asymptotic analysis, sorting/searching, hash tables (collision resolution), trees (BST/AVL), graphs (BFS/DFS, shortest paths). Use visual tools for intuition; practice with progressively harder problems.
keyTakeaways: Understand Big-O for time/space; compare algorithms under constraints.
Hashing: collisions are inevitable; master chaining and open addressing.
Traversal patterns (inorder/preorder/postorder) recur; be fluent converting recursive to iterative.
Graphs: BFS/DFS templates + Dijkstra/toposort pay off across problems.

resources.title: VisuAlgo (interactive DSA visualizations)
resources.description: Animations for lists, trees, hashing, graphs.

notes.title: Programming Concepts: OOP, Virtual Functions, Exceptions
notes.content: Recurrent essay/code-trace topics: inheritance vs composition, runtime polymorphism (virtual/override), constructors/destructors and RAII (C++), Java exceptions and hierarchy.
keyTakeaways: Polymorphism = call through base pointer, dispatch to derived via virtual functions.
Prefer composition over inheritance for flexibility; know when to use abstract classes/interfaces.
Exception handling: try/catch/finally; checked vs unchecked (Java); RAII for deterministic cleanup in C++.

notes.title: Databases: Normalization, ERD, Relational Model, SQL
notes.content: Be comfortable with 1NF/2NF/3NF (and BCNF), ER modeling, keys/relationships, and writing/optimizing SQL queries. Know merits/drawbacks of denormalization.
keyTakeaways: Normalization reduces redundancy and anomalies; most schemas target 3NF/BCNF.
Design ERDs from narrative specs; map to relational schemas cleanly.
Practice SQL (joins, subqueries, GROUP BY/HAVING) and read official docs.

notes.title: Networking: OSI/TCP-IP, Protocols, Routing, NAT, IPv4 vs IPv6
notes.content: Map OSI layers to TCP/IP stack, know HTTP/TLS basics, and compare Link-State vs Distance-Vector routing. Understand NAT and header differences between IPv4 and IPv6.
keyTakeaways: OSI is a model; TCP/IP is the practical stack used on the Internet.
Routing: Link-State (e.g., OSPF) vs Distance-Vector (e.g., RIP) – trade-offs in convergence/overhead.
IPv6 simplifies headers and expands address space; NAT mitigates IPv4 scarcity.

notes.title: Software Engineering: SDLC, Agile/Spiral, Testing, Estimation
notes.content: Understand Waterfall, Incremental, Spiral, and Agile (Scrum/Kanban). Know unit/integration/system testing and SQA roles. Be able to outline cost estimation (COCOMO-level) in essays.
keyTakeaways: Pick lifecycle models based on risk, scope, and volatility of requirements.
Testing pyramid: unit → integration → system; smoke tests for quick validation.
SQA builds processes that prevent defects, not just detect them.

notes.title: Web Technologies: HTML Forms, JavaScript/DOM, REST & AJAX
notes.content: Be exam-ready on HTML form semantics, JS fundamentals and DOM events, REST principles and AJAX/XHR/fetch patterns. Know client vs server responsibilities.
keyTakeaways: Use semantic HTML for accessibility and robustness.
DOM events + JS control client-side behavior; REST defines resource-oriented APIs.
AJAX enables partial page updates; understand fetch/XHR basics.

notes.title: Computer Graphics & Image Processing: Raster vs Vector, Transforms, Sobel/HistEq
notes.content: Understand rasterization vs ray tracing, color models, 2D transforms, and basic image processing tasks that often appear (Sobel edges, histogram equalization).
keyTakeaways: Raster = pixel grid; vector = geometric primitives; ray tracing simulates light paths.
Image processing pipelines frequently ask for steps/intuition, not code.
Know use-cases for RGB vs HSI/HSV; CMY/CMYK for print.

notes.title: Security: Malware, HTTPS/TLS, AuthN/AuthZ, OWASP Top 10
notes.content: Essentials: types of malware; encryption/authentication basics; TLS/HTTPS in the web stack; database security (access control, SQL injection prevention); web risks from OWASP Top 10.
keyTakeaways: TLS secures transport; HTTPS = HTTP over TLS with certificates.
Apply least-privilege, hashing+salting for passwords, parameterized queries for SQL.
OWASP Top 10 is a must-cite list for web risks in essays.

notes.title: Problem-Solving & Coding Practice (MCQs + Implementations)
notes.content: Blend MCQs (to shore up facts) with coding drills. Use structured study plans and interactive judges.
keyTakeaways: Follow a curated plan (Crash Course/Grind lists) to cover breadth efficiently.
Alternate topic study with 2–3 targeted problems the same day.
Review solutions and build a personal snippet library.

notes.title: CSS Pakistan: Syllabus & Past Papers (Computer Science)
notes.content: For FPSC CSS Computer Science, align prep with official syllabus and drill past papers (2016–2024 latest; earlier years too). Use these for MCQs and essays alike.
keyTakeaways: Download the official syllabus PDF and map each topic to your notes.
Practice under timed conditions; write mini-essays and code by hand.
Cross-check changes each year on FPSC site.

notes.title: Computer Architecture & DMA (bonus refreshers for OS/IO questions)
notes.content: Understand the role of DMA in offloading CPU during I/O, and how interrupts/exceptions interplay with CPU pipelines.
keyTakeaways: DMA is a bus master performing high-speed transfers between peripherals and memory.
Processor enables DMA channels and coordinates via interrupts upon completion.
